question.text: The ionization enthalpy of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msup><mi>Na</mi><mo>+</mo></msup></math> formation from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi>Na</mi><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mfenced></msub></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>495</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>8</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kJ</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo></math> while the electron gain enthalpy of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Br</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>325</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>0</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kJ</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>. Given the lattice enthalpy of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaBr</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>-</mo><mn>728</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>4</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kJ</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo> </mo><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> . The energy for the formation of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>NaBr</mi></math> ionic solid is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced><mo>-</mo></mfenced><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><mi>_</mi><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mi>kJ</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>

solution.text:
ΔHformation =IE1+ΔHeg1+LE

=495.8+-325+-728.4

=-557.6

=-5576×10-1KJ/mol .

Note: The above calculation is not for

ΔHformation  but for ΔHReaction 

But on the basis of given data it is the best ans.
